title: 4D-STEM Characterization of Stainless Steel 316L after Corrosion in Lead-bismuth Eutectic
content: Lead-bismuth eutectic (LBE) is a highly efficient liquid metal coolant with promising applications in high temperature cooling applications. However, the corrosive nature of LBE on structural materials presents a significant challenge to its implementation in advanced nuclear reactors. Previous study has shown that deformation-induced twin boundaries can facilitate the penetration of LBE into steel in the early stage [1]. And steel ferritization will occur together with the LBE corrosion which transforms face-centered cubic (FCC) steel matrix to body-centered cubic (BCC) structure. In our research, we employed four-dimensional scanning transmission electron microscopy (4D-STEM) [2] and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) elemental mapping to investigate the intergranular corrosion of austenitic stainless steel 316L by LBE.
